Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Comparative morphological analysis of the hand and wrist in Ardipithecus ramidus and Miocene hominoids

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 4.4 million year old fossil species Ardipithecus ramidus may represent one of the oldest human ancestors, and it holds potentially critical insights into the initial evolutionary divergence of humans and chimpanzees from their last common ancestor. Establishing the primitive condition (or 'starting point') for that divergence would have transformative implications for nearly every aspect of research on human origins and evolutionary biology. Unexpectedly, the skeleton of Ar. ramidus has been described as differing from that of the living apes more than had been predicted - instead resembling that of more primitive apes from the early Miocene epoch. In particular, some have argued that the hand and wrist retain features related to cautious climbing and palmigrady (use of an extended wrist and weight-bearing palm, adapted for moving above branches). Much of the anatomy, however, has not been examined in a rigorous, quantitative context, and comparisons with Miocene apes have been limited. The project will analyze Ar. ramidus and a broad comparative sample of extant primates and fossil species using three- dimensional (3D) morphometrics to test the hypotheses that: 1) Ar. ramidus used its hands in a manner inconsistent with advanced vertical climbing, suspension, and/or knuckle-walking as used by living apes; and 2) Ar. ramidus is a hominin (i.e., more closely related to humans than chimpanzees). If these hypotheses are upheld, then models of hominin origins cannot assume a highly suspensory or knuckle- walking ancestor, or one that engaged in vigorous vertical climbing. Consequently, explanations for many human adaptations would have to be drastically modified.

All metric data and the generated 3D digital models of most specimens will be available via a public online database or provided to museums housing the original material. Importantly, the 3D models constitute a record of irreplaceable fossils and skeletal material from several domestic and international institutions. This award supports early-career scientists, including one Asian American principal investigator (PI), and one of the co-PIs will foster collaboration between American and Spanish researchers. Finally, the project provides vital opportunities for students to learn skills in anatomical imaging and computer modeling, which are indispensable in the basic sciences and biomedicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The fossil species Ardipithecus ramidus from the site of Aramis, Ethiopia dates to 4.4 million years ago and may represent one of the oldest human ancestors. As such, it holds potentially critical clues about the last common ancestor of humans and the African apes. Reconstructing the anatomy and adaptations of that last common ancestor is essential if we are to understand the “starting point” for evolution of our lineage and its adaptations. A number of features of the teeth, cranium, and pelvis in Ardipithecus demonstrate that it is a member of the human branch of the primate phylogenetic tree (i.e., a hominin). However, other aspects of its skeleton have been described as being substantially different from that of the living apes, more so than had been expected by researchers. Rather, its anatomy has been interpreted to resemble the generalized quadrupedal and careful-climbing primates from the earlier Miocene epoch. Specifically, the anatomy of the hand and wrist played a central role in the initial locomotor reconstruction of Ardipithecus as some argued it indicates retained adaptations to a primitive form of quadrupedalism including palmigrady (i.e., a weight-bearing palm with an extended wrist and fingers, which are adaptations for deliberate above-branch locomotion). However, important aspects of hand/wrist anatomy had not been examined in a rigorous, comparative, and quantitative context, and critical comparisons with Miocene apes were limited. Therefore, the goal of the funded research was to analyze the hand and wrist anatomy of Ardipithecus along with material from a broad sample of living and fossil primate species using three-dimensional (3D) morphometric data to test the hypotheses that: 1) Ardipithecus exhibits anatomy inconsistent with advanced vertical climbing, suspension, and/or knuckle-walking as used by living apes; and 2) Ardipithecus is a hominin (i.e., more closely related to humans than to chimpanzees).

        To date, the raw data has been fully acquired but final analyses are still in progress. Our preliminary results do support the notion that Ardipithecus is a hominin, but exhibits little to no morphological adaptation to monkey-like pronograde palmigrade hand postures (i.e., contacting the substrate with a fully extended wrist and involving significant push-off by the digits) during locomotion. Furthermore, monkey-like palmigrady is unlikely to have been a key locomotor behavior used by early hominins. Instead, the earliest hominins were likely to have incorporated climbing and suspensory behaviors broadly similar to the African apes (chimpanzees and gorillas), although they may have incorporated “palmigrade”-like postures in ways that all of the extant apes are capable (without engaging a fully extended wrist or pushing off with the fingers). This is a critical result for understanding the primitive condition from which the human hand has evolved, because it suggests that many aspects of the human hand facilitating greater mobility and human-like grasping are derived characteristics in the hominin lineage, rather than being primitive retentions.

        Broader Impacts: Advancing discovery: Establishing the primitive condition for humans with regard to anatomy and behavior is essential for explaining evolution within our lineage. Analysis of the Ardipithecus fossils thus holds critical and potentially transformative implications for nearly every aspect of research on human origins and evolution. Promoting new scholarship: Two of the primary investigators (PIs) and both co-primary investigators (co-PIs) are in the early stages of their careers, and the project will significantly advance their research goals in human origins. Increasing minority representation: One of the PIs is an Asian American, which is an underrepresented group in biological anthropology. Fostering international collaboration: One of the co-PIs is a citizen of Spain, and an important portion of the project has involved the analysis of fossils from Spain that he has played a key role in describing. His participation significantly fostered collaboration between American and Spanish scientists. Student participation: The project provided opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in anthropology, biology, and medicine (at Midwestern University, University of Colorado Denver/Anschutz, Stony Brook University, and University of Southern California) to work on various aspects of the project and/or to develop “spin-off” research of their own using the data collected. These students learned skills in imaging and computer modeling that have become indispensable in biomedical and STEM research. Data in the form of 3D computer models of hand and foot bones will promote future student participation because these models can be used to address numerous research problems (large and small) that extend beyond the current project’s scope without incurring additional financial costs. Data and resource sharing: All data, including 3D models of most of the specimens, will be available to researchers and educators directly from the project participants or distributed by museums that house the original specimens. Importantly, the 3D data provide a full digital record of irreplaceable and delicate fossils and comparative primate skeletal material from a number of domestic and international science museums.
